Defending Against Data Reconstruction Attacks in Federated Learning:
An Information Theory Approach

Qi Tana, Qi Lib, Yi Zhaoc, ğŸ–‚, Zhuotao Liub, Xiaobing Guod, and Ke Xua, ğŸ–‚

aDepartment of Computer Science and Technology, Tsinghua University
bInstitute for Network Science and Cyberspace, Tsinghua University
cSchool of Cyberspace Science and Technology, Beijing Institute of Technology
dLenovo Research
Abstract

Federated Learning (FL) trains a black-box and high-dimensional model among different clients by exchanging parameters instead of direct data sharing, which mitigates the privacy leak incurred by machine learning. However, FL still suffers from membership inference attacks (MIA) or data reconstruction attacks (DRA). In particular, an attacker can extract the information from local datasets by constructing DRA, which cannot be effectively throttled by existing techniques, e.g., Differential Privacy (DP).

In this paper, we aim to ensure a strong privacy guarantee for FL under DRA. We prove that reconstruction errors under DRA are constrained by the information acquired by an attacker, which means that constraining the transmitted information can effectively throttle DRA. To quantify the information leakage incurred by FL, we establish a channel model, which depends on the upper bound of joint mutual information between the local dataset and multiple transmitted parameters. Moreover, the channel model indicates that the transmitted information can be constrained through data space operation, which can improve training efficiency and the model accuracy under constrained information. According to the channel model, we propose algorithms to constrain the information transmitted in a single round of local training. With a limited number of training rounds, the algorithms ensure that the total amount of transmitted information is limited. Furthermore, our channel model can be applied to various privacy-enhancing techniques (such as DP) to enhance privacy guarantees against DRA. Extensive experiments with real-world datasets validate the effectiveness of our methods.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL)Â [43, 61, 64, 65] is a new form of machine learning (ML), which protects privacy by transmitting gradients or parameters to avoid sharing raw data. Specifically, the parameters form a communication channel between the server and each client, so the server gets information from local datasets via such channels. Based on the Data Processing Inequality (DPI) [15], communication by parameters, which is a deterministic mapping of local data, instead of raw data, reduces the risk of data privacy. However, recent studies reveal that the parameter channel of FL still leaks privacy. For example, multiple literature indicates that adversaries can conduct membership inference attacks (MIA) with uploaded model parametersÂ [50, 46, 44, 42, 13, 10], which breaks the anonymity of data privacy. Moreover, adversaries can completely steal training data by data reconstruction attacks (DRA)Â [28, 66, 11, 24, 12], resulting in serious privacy issues in FL.

In order to enhance privacy protection for FL, dimension reductionÂ [37, 48, 54] or differential privacy (DP) [3, 35, 36] are widely adopted approaches. However, dimension reduction lacks theoretical guarantees of the defense ability against DRA, so it cannot flexibly configure defense capabilities according to different privacy requirements. DPâ€™s privacy protection can provide theoretical guarantees (e.g., the privacy budget Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon) for MIA attacksÂ [7, 22]. It aims to guarantee that changing any data point will not significantly affect the output distribution of a system. This goal is different from the one in defending against DRA, which focuses on preventing the attacker from reconstructing the whole distribution of the local dataset. Thus DP still cannot defend against DRA attacksÂ [14, 39, 26, 7, 22]. For instance, in DP-SGD, algorithms with identical privacy budget but different training hyper-parameters (e.g., different batch size BğµB) cannot guarantee the same success rate for DRAÂ [26]. Moreover, quantifying information leakage is the basis for defending against DRA attacks. Previous technique like Quantitative Information Flow (QIF)111QIF focuses on a special security concern, namely the probability of guessing a secret in one tryÂ [5, 53]. This security concern is different from the one in DRA, where DRA focuses on reconstructing the whole distribution of local data. [5] quantifies information leak under a white-box and time-invariant setting[49]. It requires the knowledge of the correlation between the distributions of inputs and outputs, which cannot hold in FL systems.

It is difficult to defend against DRA attacks in FL due to the following challenges. (i) the black-box model. For DNN-based models, the correlation between the input distribution and output distribution is extremely complex, and we cannot obtain the exact mapping function between the two distributions, making theoretical analysis impossible. (ii) the high-dimensional parameter space. Traditional mathematical tools (e.g., eigen-decomposition) cannot process high-dimensional parameter spaces on the scale of thousands of millions due to the requirements for large-scale storage and high-performance computing. (iii) the time-variant system. During the training process, constant parameter updates change the model at each step, leading to a time-variant system in FL. The time-variant system, which changes the output distributions accordingly, leads to dynamic information leakage, requiring continuously changing quantifications.

To address the above challenges, we develop a theoretical framework based on mutual information (MI)222Mutual information Iâ€‹(X;Y)ğ¼ğ‘‹ğ‘ŒI(X;Y) [16, 51, 29] represents the uncertainty decrement of Xğ‘‹X when we observe Yğ‘ŒY. to evaluate privacy leakage caused by DRA in FL, and design methods to constrain information leakage to defend against DRA attacks. Specifically, we demonstrate that the lower bound of mean squared error (MSE), which serves as an indicator of DRAâ€™s precision in reconstruction (i.e., the smaller MSE means the higher precision for the attacker), is determined by the amount of acquired information, i.e., the MI between the local dataset and the shared parameters. Thus, MI can be utilized as the indicator for quantifying the information leakage in FL. Then we build a channel model to analyze information leaks under the black-box setting of FL. Through our proposed channel model, we find that the transmitted information (i.e., the information leakage) is decided by two factors: the channel capacity Cğ¶C, which represents the maximal ability to transmit information in a single training round; and the optimization rounds nğ‘›n, which is correlated to the information accumulation. For example, if the channel capacity is bounded by a threshold Îºğœ…\kappa, and the number of optimization rounds is less than nğ‘›n, then the total amount of information leakage is less than nâ‹…Îºâ‹…ğ‘›ğœ…n\cdot\kappa. Furthermore, our channel model can analyze various privacy-enhancing methods in defending against DRA, including DP, gradient compression, and utilizing large batch size.

Based on the channel model, we utilize DPI to transform the operations (e.g., eigen-decomposition and adding noise) of constraining channel capacity from the parameter space to the data space. This transformation significantly improves the training efficiency and the model accuracy of the high dimensional and time-variant model under constrained information leakage. Specifically, our protecting goal is to decide the covariance matrix for the added noise according to a given data distribution ğ‘«ğ‘«{\bm{D}}, which ensures privacy protection by constraining the reconstruction error above a certain threshold. Compared to conventional protection techniques, which directly deal with parameters after gradient mapping, constraining in the data space has two distinct advantages: firstly, it makes the computational complexity independent of the optimization rounds nğ‘›n and the modelâ€™s dimensionality dmsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘šd_{m}, reducing it from ğ’ªâ€‹(nâ‹…dm)ğ’ªâ‹…ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘š\mathcal{O}(n\cdot d_{m}) to ğ’ªâ€‹(dD)ğ’ªsubscriptğ‘‘ğ·\mathcal{O}(d_{D}), where dDsubscriptğ‘‘ğ·d_{D} denotes the dimensionality of the data and dDâ‰ªdmmuch-less-thansubscriptğ‘‘ğ·subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘šd_{D}\ll d_{m}. Secondly, data space preserves the correlations between data attributes, hence we can leverage the prior knowledge of relative importance to implement stronger safeguards for the critical attributes, which enhances the capability to balance the utility and the privacy.

Finally, according to the theoretical results, we propose three implementations for constraining the channel capacity. These implementations incorporate different prior knowledge in defending against DRA, which can be employed to flexibly balance the utility and the privacy.

In summary, the contributions of our paper are as follows:

  • â€¢

    We demonstrate that the amount of transmitted information decides the lower bound of the reconstruction error for DRA attacks.

  • â€¢

    We establish a channel model to quantify the information leakage of the black-box model in FL, which can be applied to analyze various privacy-enhancing methods for defending against DRA.

  • â€¢

    We theoretically constrain the transmitted information through the operation in data space instead of parameter space for the first time and demonstrate that it significantly improves the training efficiency and the model accuracy under constrained information leakage.

  • â€¢

    By incorporating different prior knowledge, we propose three implementations to constrain channel capacity, which can be utilized to flexibly balance the utility and the privacy.

  • â€¢

    Extensive experiments demonstrate that the newly proposed methods effectively enhance the safety, efficiency, and flexibility of FL.

2 Background and Preliminary

This paper studies the FL problem based on information theory. Specifically, in the FL scenario, the server and clients communicate by sending model parameters. Even without direct data sharing, the MI between shared parameters and the local dataset grows accordingly, which enhances the ability for attackers to conduct DRA attacks. For clarity purposes, Tab.Â 1 lists major notations used in the paper, and we will describe the remaining variables when they are utilized.

2.1 Federated Learning

Regarding FL, a specific client, namely the victim, receives the initial parameter ğ‘¾1subscriptğ‘¾1{\bm{W}}_{1} from the server in a specific communication round and conducts the optimization process with the victimâ€™s dataset as

ğ‘¾t+1â†ğ‘¾tâˆ’Î·â‹…âˆ‡ğ‘¾Fâ€‹(ğ‘¾t;ğ‘«),t=1,â‹¯,E,formulae-sequenceâ†subscriptğ‘¾ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘¾ğ‘¡â‹…ğœ‚subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¾ğ¹subscriptğ‘¾ğ‘¡ğ‘«ğ‘¡1â‹¯ğ¸{\bm{W}}_{t+1}\leftarrow{\bm{W}}_{t}-\eta\cdot\nabla_{{\bm{W}}}F({\bm{W}}_{t};{\bm{D}}),\;t=1,\,\cdots,\,E, (1)

where Eğ¸E is the number of local steps. Then the victim sends ğ‘¾E+1subscriptğ‘¾ğ¸1{\bm{W}}_{E+1} back to the server. If we rewrite ğ‘¾1subscriptğ‘¾1{\bm{W}}_{1} and ğ‘¾E+1subscriptğ‘¾ğ¸1{\bm{W}}_{E+1} as ğ‘¾isubscriptğ‘¾ğ‘–{\bm{W}}_{i} and ğ‘¾osubscriptğ‘¾ğ‘œ{\bm{W}}_{o} respectively, the two parameters form a communication channel for information transmission (as illustrated in Fig. 2), and the local optimization process defined in Eq.Â (1) loads information from the dataset to the communication channel. Finally, the server collects the parameters from different clients (including the victim) for aggregation as

2.2 Information Theory

Differential Entropy. The differential entropy of a random variable ğ‘¿ğ‘¿{\bm{X}} is defined as follows

hâ€‹(ğ‘¿)=âˆ’âˆ«ğ‘¿fâ€‹(ğ’™)â€‹logâ¡fâ€‹(ğ’™)â€‹ğ‘‘ğ’™,â„ğ‘¿subscriptğ‘¿ğ‘“ğ’™ğ‘“ğ’™differential-dğ’™h({\bm{X}})=-\int_{{\bm{X}}}f({\bm{x}})\log f({\bm{x}})\,d{\bm{x}}, (3)

which is utilized to describe the degree of random uncertainty. For a dataset with high information entropy, i.e., a dataset with plentiful information, it is difficult for an attacker to conduct DRA attacks. While for the dataset with low information entropy, the opposite is true.

However, calculating the differential entropy by Eq.Â (3) is infeasible in practice since we cannot obtain the distribution function of the target variable. Therefore, we use the maximum entropy distribution to analyze the worst-case scenario. Specifically, with ğ”¼â€‹[ğ‘¿]=ğğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘¿ğ{\mathbb{E}}[{\bm{X}}]={\bm{\mu}} and Câ€‹oâ€‹vâ€‹(ğ‘¿)=ğšºğ¶ğ‘œğ‘£ğ‘¿ğšºCov({\bm{X}})={\bm{\Sigma}}, the maximum entropy distribution is the Gaussian distribution, i.e., hâ€‹(ğ‘¿)â‰¤hâ€‹(ğ’©â€‹(ğ,ğšº))â„ğ‘¿â„ğ’©ğğšºh({\bm{X}})\leq h({\mathcal{N}}({\bm{\mu}},{\bm{\Sigma}})).

Mutual Information. For two random variables ğ‘¿ğ‘¿{\bm{X}} and ğ’€ğ’€{\bm{Y}}, the mutual information between them is

Iâ€‹(ğ‘¿;ğ’€)=hâ€‹(ğ‘¿)âˆ’hâ€‹(ğ‘¿|ğ’€)=hâ€‹(ğ’€)âˆ’hâ€‹(ğ’€|ğ‘¿).ğ¼ğ‘¿ğ’€â„ğ‘¿â„conditionalğ‘¿ğ’€â„ğ’€â„conditionalğ’€ğ‘¿I({\bm{X}};{\bm{Y}})=h({\bm{X}})-h({\bm{X}}|{\bm{Y}})=h({\bm{Y}})-h({\bm{Y}}|{\bm{X}}). (4)

Specifically, the mutual information Iâ€‹(ğ‘¿;ğ’€)ğ¼ğ‘¿ğ’€I({\bm{X}};{\bm{Y}}) is a symmetric function, which describes the random uncertainty decrement of ğ‘¿ğ‘¿{\bm{X}} when we observe ğ’€ğ’€{\bm{Y}}, and vice versa.

Specifically, in this paper, we utilize Iâ€‹(ğ‘«;ğ‘¾i,ğ‘¾o)ğ¼ğ‘«subscriptğ‘¾ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¾ğ‘œI({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}_{i},{\bm{W}}_{o}) to quantify the information leakage in FL. The intuition is that when an attacker observes the communication parameters of a victim, the random uncertainty of the victimâ€™s local dataset will decrease, which implies the attacker can extract information from the victimâ€™s local dataset to achieve more precise DRA.

Channel Capacity. The key factor in describing a communication channel is channel capacity. In information theory, traditional channel capacity is defined by the maximum MI between the sending variable ğ‘¿ğ‘¿{\bm{X}} and the receiving variable ğ’€ğ’€{\bm{Y}}, i.e., C=maxpâ€‹(ğ’™)â¡Iâ€‹(ğ‘¿;ğ’€)ğ¶subscriptğ‘ğ’™ğ¼ğ‘¿ğ’€C=\max_{p({\bm{x}})}\;I({\bm{X}};{\bm{Y}}), which is the maximum information that we can send by information coding.

In this work, the sending variable is ğ‘«ğ‘«{\bm{D}}, while the receiving variable is ğ‘¾osubscriptğ‘¾ğ‘œ{\bm{W}}_{o}, which is decided by the variables ğ‘¾isubscriptğ‘¾ğ‘–{\bm{W}}_{i} and ğ‘«ğ‘«{\bm{D}} according to Eq.Â (1), hence the channel capacity can be formalized as C=maxpâ€‹(ğ’˜o)â¡Iâ€‹(ğ‘«;ğ‘¾o|ğ‘¾i)ğ¶subscriptğ‘subscriptğ’˜ğ‘œğ¼ğ‘«conditionalsubscriptğ‘¾ğ‘œsubscriptğ‘¾ğ‘–C=\max_{p({\bm{w}}_{o})}\;I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}_{o}|{\bm{W}}_{i}), which is the upper bound of the transmitted information.

The reasons for choosing MI to measure the information leakage. Prior research like QIF and g-leakage utilizes min-entropy [5, 53] to measure the information leakage, which can only work in a white-box and time-invariant system [49]. However, FL is a black-box (e.g., deep neural networks) and time-variant (e.g., parameter updating in each round) system. Hence, these techniques are not applicable. Moreover, min-entropy is unsuitable for modeling the attack against FL, e.g., DRA. The min-entropy focuses on measuring the uncertainty of guessing the most likely output of random sources [23, 30], which is more related to cryptographic systems. However, in DRA, the attackerâ€™s target is to reconstruct the whole data distribution based on the victimâ€™s sharing parameters, instead of guessing a most likely data point. Therefore, the precision of DRA attacks depends on the difference between two distributions, which must take all data of the distributions into consideration. In this scenario, the Shannon entropy, i.e., MI, which is based on the expectation metric, can accurately measure the correlation between the whole distributions, thus is more suitable for analyzing the information leakage issue under DRA. Therefore, we choose MI to measure the information leakage in FL.

3 Key Observation and Method Overview

3.1 Key Observation

Regarding FL, different clients jointly optimize the model by passing parameters to the server instead of raw data. Since the parameters are the mapping of the original data, the attacker can still reconstruct the private data from the parameters, thereby stealing privacy. Correspondingly, the client can preserve privacy by perturbing the transmitted parameters. Therefore, we build a channel model to calculate the privacy data contained in parameters. Moreover, based on the quantitative results, the privacy data in parameters can be flexibly adjusted to meet various privacy requirements.

In this section, we establish a formal correlation between the transmitted information, i.e., the MI, and the reconstruction error of DRA by the following theorem.

Theorem 1 (Lower bound for reconstruction error).

For any random variable ğƒğƒ{\bm{D}}, ğƒâˆˆâ„dğƒsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘{\bm{D}}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} and ğ–ğ–{\bm{W}}, ğ–âˆˆâ„mğ–superscriptâ„ğ‘š{\bm{W}}\in\mathbb{R}^{m}, we have

ğ”¼â€‹[â€–ğ‘«âˆ’ğ‘«^â€‹(ğ‘¾)â€–2/d]â‰¥e2â€‹hâ€‹(ğ‘«)/d2â€‹Ï€â€‹eâ€‹eâˆ’2â€‹Iâ€‹(ğ‘«;ğ‘¾)/d,ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormğ‘«^ğ‘«ğ‘¾2ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘’2â„ğ‘«ğ‘‘2ğœ‹ğ‘’superscriptğ‘’2ğ¼ğ‘«ğ‘¾ğ‘‘\mathbb{E}[\|{\bm{D}}-\hat{{\bm{D}}}({\bm{W}})\|^{2}/d]\geq\frac{e^{2h({\bm{D}})/d}}{2\pi e}e^{-2I({\bm{D}};\;{\bm{W}})/d}, (5)

where ğƒ^â€‹(ğ–)^ğƒğ–\hat{{\bm{D}}}({\bm{W}}) is an estimator of ğƒğƒ{\bm{D}} constructed by ğ–ğ–{\bm{W}}.

Specifically, Eq.Â (5) denotes the lower bound of MSE in DRA, which represents the optimal error for data reconstruction. In the FL scenario, we denote ğ‘«ğ‘«{\bm{D}} as the target data distribution and ğ‘¾ğ‘¾{\bm{W}} as the shared parameter. Therefore hâ€‹(ğ‘«)â„ğ‘«h({\bm{D}}) is the entropy of the target data distribution, which is a constant during machine learning. Moreover, the lower bound is negatively correlated to MI, i.e., Iâ€‹(ğ‘«;ğ‘¾)ğ¼ğ‘«ğ‘¾I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}), which indicates that if ğ‘¾ğ‘¾{\bm{W}} contains more information of target data ğ‘«ğ‘«{\bm{D}}, i.e., a larger Iâ€‹(ğ‘«;ğ‘¾)ğ¼ğ‘«ğ‘¾I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}), the attacker can achieve a more precise reconstruction of ğ‘«ğ‘«{\bm{D}}. Consequently, large Iâ€‹(ğ‘«;ğ‘¾)ğ¼ğ‘«ğ‘¾I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}) exacerbates the privacy issue.

In FL, MI increases as the number of optimization rounds increases, thereby enhancing the precision of DRA. Therefore, constraining the overall MI in FL is the way to restrict the precision of DRA. To this end, we build a channel model to measure the increase of MI in Sec.Â 4, and propose three implementation methods to limit MI within a certain threshold.

3.2 Method Overview

In this study, we develop techniques to enhance FLâ€™s capability of privacy protection, in particular, defending against DRA. Normally, FL transmits information from the local dataset to the server by model parameters, i.e., the parameter channel. The transmitted information can be employed by an attacker to conduct various attacks. Hence, the objective of privacy protection is to constrain the amount of transmitted information. Specifically, for DRA, the reconstruction error is lower bounded by a function of MI (Thm.Â 1), which indicates that a smaller MI leads to a larger reconstruction error. Therefore, our technique is devoted to limiting the reconstruction ability by constraining the total MI in FL.

Threat Model. In this work, we focus on privacy leaks incurred by DRA in FL. Specifically, the attacker aims to reconstruct the data distribution ğ‘«ğ‘«{\bm{D}} of a specific client (i.e., the victim) via parameters shared by the victim. We assume that the attacker can get the transmitted parameters by the victim (i.e., ğ‘¾isubscriptğ‘¾ğ‘–{\bm{W}}_{i} and ğ‘¾osubscriptğ‘¾ğ‘œ{\bm{W}}_{o}). Then the attacker can reconstruct a data distribution ğ‘«^â€‹(ğ‘¾i,ğ‘¾o)^ğ‘«subscriptğ‘¾ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¾ğ‘œ\hat{{\bm{D}}}({\bm{W}}_{i},{\bm{W}}_{o}) to approximate the target data distribution ğ‘«ğ‘«{\bm{D}} (AppendixÂ A explains the details of DRA).

Our goal is to constrain the private data that the attacker can obtain according to the transmitted parameters in FL. Therefore, the attackerâ€™s ability to construct the DRA attack is limited.

Controlled parameter channel. As illustrated in Fig.Â 1, to restrict the transmitted information, we transform the noiseless parameter ğ‘¾osubscriptğ‘¾ğ‘œ{\bm{W}}_{o} to a noisy Gaussian channel by adding Gaussian noise ğ’©â€‹(ğŸ,ğšº)ğ’©0ğšº{\mathcal{N}}(\bm{0},{\bm{\Sigma}}) to it. Based on the theorem of Gaussian channel in information theoryÂ [15], the noisy Gaussian channel has limited capability for information transmission, which is the channel capacity. Thus, with the eigenvalues of ğ‘¾osubscriptğ‘¾ğ‘œ{\bm{W}}_{o}, we derive a formula fâ€‹(ğšº)ğ‘“ğšºf({\bm{\Sigma}}) to characterize the channel capacity of the Gaussian channel by the maximum entropy distribution. Finally, we solve the equation fâ€‹(ğšº)=Îºğ‘“ğšºğœ…f({\bm{\Sigma}})=\kappa to decide ğšºğšº{\bm{\Sigma}} for constraining the transmitted information within a threshold Îºğœ…\kappa. We will explain how the controlled parameter channel constrains transmitted information in Sec.Â 4 and Sec.Â 5.1.

Constraining channel capacity in the data space. To overcome the efficiency issue caused by the high dimensional and time-variant model in FL, we theoretically transform operations of constraining channel capacity from the parameter space to the data space. Specifically, the information contained in the resulting parameter is decided by the input data, thus constraining channel capacity can be achieved by restricting the information contained in the input data. Moreover, this transformation significantly improves the training efficiency and the model accuracy under constrained information leakage. We will explain the transformation in Sec.Â 5.2.

Theoretically, when an attacker observes ğ‘¾isubscriptğ‘¾ğ‘–{\bm{W}}_{i} and ğ‘¾osubscriptğ‘¾ğ‘œ{\bm{W}}_{o}, the random uncertainty of the local data ğ‘«ğ‘«{\bm{D}} decreases, which means the attacker gets more information to conduct DRA attacks, leading to more precise reconstruction. The amount of random uncertainty reduction Î”â€‹IÎ”ğ¼\Delta I (i.e., information leakage) in a round can be formalized as

Î”â€‹I=Iâ€‹(ğ‘«;ğ‘¾i,ğ‘¾o)âˆ’Iâ€‹(ğ‘«;ğ‘¾i)=Iâ€‹(ğ‘«;ğ‘¾o|ğ‘¾i),Î”ğ¼ğ¼ğ‘«subscriptğ‘¾ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¾ğ‘œğ¼ğ‘«subscriptğ‘¾ğ‘–ğ¼ğ‘«conditionalsubscriptğ‘¾ğ‘œsubscriptğ‘¾ğ‘–\Delta I=I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}_{i},{\bm{W}}_{o})-I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}_{i})=I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}_{o}|{\bm{W}}_{i}),

which means the attacker gets Î”â€‹IÎ”ğ¼\Delta I information from ğ‘«ğ‘«{\bm{D}} (as illustrated in Fig.Â 2). Moreover, this privacy leak occurs in each optimization round, which results in an increase in MI and consistently increases the risk of privacy.

As aforementioned, for defending against DRA, our technique constructs a controlled parameter channel by limiting Î”â€‹IÎ”ğ¼\Delta I to less than a threshold Îºğœ…\kappa for all optimization rounds. Then together with the bounded optimization rounds nğ‘›n, we provide nâ‹…Îºâ‹…ğ‘›ğœ…n\cdot\kappa guarantee for the total information leakage, thereby constraining the attack precision of DRA.

4 Channel Model of the Information Leakage

In this section, we formalize the problem of FL into a communication process based on information theory and then unfold the recurrent communication process into a time-dependent Markov Chain. Finally, we build a channel model to calculate the MI according to the unfolded communication process.

4.1 Accumulation of Mutual Information

As illustrated in Fig.Â 2, in the FL scenario, a specific client, i.e., the victim, communicates with the server through a logic channel: the parameters ğ‘¾isubscriptğ‘¾ğ‘–{\bm{W}}_{i} and ğ‘¾osubscriptğ‘¾ğ‘œ{\bm{W}}_{o}. Specifically, There are three different information flows: the ingress flow, i.e., the received parameter ğ‘¾isubscriptğ‘¾ğ‘–{\bm{W}}_{i}, which determines the background knowledge possessed by the server (i.e., the attacker); the egress flow, which is the information contained in the sharing parameter ğ‘¾osubscriptğ‘¾ğ‘œ{\bm{W}}_{o}; and the internal flow, i.e., local optimization process, which loads the information contained in the local dataset to the egress flow. Particularly, due to privacy requests, the victim only communicates with the server by ğ‘¾isubscriptğ‘¾ğ‘–{\bm{W}}_{i} and ğ‘¾osubscriptğ‘¾ğ‘œ{\bm{W}}_{o}.

The information leakage of the communication channel depends on the MI increment when the server observes ğ‘¾osubscriptğ‘¾ğ‘œ{\bm{W}}_{o}. Thus, it can be formalized as

Iâ€‹(ğ‘«;ğ‘¾i,ğ‘¾o)=Iâ€‹(ğ‘«;ğ‘¾i)âŸPrior+Iâ€‹(ğ‘«;ğ‘¾o|ğ‘¾i)âŸInformation Leakage (Î”â€‹I).ğ¼ğ‘«subscriptğ‘¾ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¾ğ‘œsubscriptâŸğ¼ğ‘«subscriptğ‘¾ğ‘–PriorsubscriptâŸğ¼ğ‘«conditionalsubscriptğ‘¾ğ‘œsubscriptğ‘¾ğ‘–Information Leakage (Î”I)I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}_{i},{\bm{W}}_{o})=\underbrace{I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}_{i})}_{\text{Prior}}+\underbrace{I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}_{o}|{\bm{W}}_{i})}_{\text{Information Leakage ($\Delta I$)}}. (6)

Eq.Â (6) is an immediate result according to the chain rule of MI. It indicates that the MI between ğ‘«ğ‘«{\bm{D}} and the joint distribution (ğ‘¾i,ğ‘¾o)subscriptğ‘¾ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¾ğ‘œ({\bm{W}}_{i},{\bm{W}}_{o}) can be divided into two parts: the prior knowledge and the information leakage Î”â€‹IÎ”ğ¼\Delta I. In the rest of this paper, we will utilize Iâ€‹(ğ‘«;ğ‘¾o|ğ‘¾i)ğ¼ğ‘«conditionalsubscriptğ‘¾ğ‘œsubscriptğ‘¾ğ‘–I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}_{o}|{\bm{W}}_{i}) instead of Î”â€‹IÎ”ğ¼\Delta I for more comprehensible analysis.

However, ğ‘¾isubscriptğ‘¾ğ‘–{\bm{W}}_{i} and ğ‘¾osubscriptğ‘¾ğ‘œ{\bm{W}}_{o} are joint distributions of different rounds, which contain multiple local learning processes. Hence, connecting Eq. (6) to the internal flow is difficult. To resolve this issue, we unfold the recurrent process to a time-dependent Markov chain. As illustrated in Fig.Â 2, there is only one local optimization process within a round from ğ‘¾i(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¾ğ‘¡ğ‘–{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i} to ğ‘¾i(t+1)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¾ğ‘¡1ğ‘–{\bm{W}}^{(t+1)}_{i}, hence we can analyze MI increment at round tğ‘¡t.

Specifically, according to Eq.Â (1) and Eq.Â (2), the relationship between ğ‘¾i(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¾ğ‘¡ğ‘–{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i} and ğ‘¾o(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¾ğ‘¡ğ‘œ{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o} in Fig.Â 2 is

ğ‘¾o(t)=ğ‘¾i(t)âˆ’Î·â‹…âˆ‡ğ‘¾Fâ€‹(ğ‘¾i(t);ğ‘«),subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¾ğ‘¡ğ‘œsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¾ğ‘¡ğ‘–â‹…ğœ‚subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¾ğ¹subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¾ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘«{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o}={\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i}-\eta\cdot\nabla_{{\bm{W}}}F({\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i};{\bm{D}}), (7)

which represents the local learning process with SGD. While for ğ‘¾o(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¾ğ‘¡ğ‘œ{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o} and ğ‘¾i(t+1)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¾ğ‘¡1ğ‘–{\bm{W}}^{(t+1)}_{i}, the relationship is

Finally, for multiple local updates, the scenario is slightly different. We denote the number of local steps in one communication round as Eğ¸E, and the total number of local steps for all communication rounds as nğ‘›n, where nğ‘›n is divisible into Eğ¸E. Where E|tconditionalğ¸ğ‘¡E\,|\,t represents we make aggregation on the server every Eğ¸E steps. If we set E=nğ¸ğ‘›E=n, the FL problem reduces to classical ML without collaboration.

Based on the former analysis, the new aggregation rule only changes Î“sâ€‹eâ€‹râ€‹vâ€‹eâ€‹rsubscriptÎ“ğ‘ ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘£ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿ\Gamma_{server} in Eq.Â (4.1), while Î“câ€‹lâ€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹nâ€‹tsubscriptÎ“ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘’ğ‘›ğ‘¡\Gamma_{client} remains the same. 5 Controlled Parameter Channel

Based on the former analysis, the important part of defending against DRA is Iâ€‹(ğ‘«;ğ‘¾~o(t)|ğ‘¾i(t))ğ¼ğ‘«conditionalsubscriptsuperscript~ğ‘¾ğ‘¡ğ‘œsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¾ğ‘¡ğ‘–I({\bm{D}};\widetilde{{\bm{W}}}^{(t)}_{o}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i}), which represents the MI increment at round tğ‘¡t. The key parameters to restrict the MI increment are ğšºğ‘¾subscriptğšºğ‘¾{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{W}}} and ğšºğšº{\bm{\Sigma}}. In this section, we first propose a method for deciding ğšºğšº{\bm{\Sigma}} that ensures Iâ€‹(ğ‘«;ğ‘¾~o(t)|ğ‘¾i(t))â‰¤Îºğ¼ğ‘«conditionalsubscriptsuperscript~ğ‘¾ğ‘¡ğ‘œsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¾ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğœ…I({\bm{D}};\widetilde{{\bm{W}}}^{(t)}_{o}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i})\leq\kappa. Then, we transform the operations for constraining MI from the parameter space to the data space and propose three implementation methods for constraining the channel capacity. Finally, we analyze existing techniques with our theoretical results in defending against DRA.

5.1 Controlled Channel Capacity

Channel capacity is the maximum ability to transmit information within a single round, i.e., maxâ¡Iâ€‹(ğ‘«;ğ‘¾~o(t)|ğ‘¾i(t))ğ¼ğ‘«conditionalsubscriptsuperscript~ğ‘¾ğ‘¡ğ‘œsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¾ğ‘¡ğ‘–\max\;I({\bm{D}};\widetilde{{\bm{W}}}^{(t)}_{o}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i}), which is the key parameter for constraining the information leakage.

To constrain the channel capacity, we have ThmÂ 2.

Theorem 2 (Channel capacity).

In this scenario, the channel capacity can be displayed as Fig.Â 5. Specifically, the channel capacity is an increasing function of Î»(t)superscriptğœ†ğ‘¡\lambda^{(t)} and a decreasing function of Ïƒ(t)superscriptğœğ‘¡\sigma^{(t)}. Moreover, it is worth noting that even the server can change the channel capacity by crafting ğ‘¾i(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¾ğ‘¡ğ‘–{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i}, the victim can constrain the transmitted information within Îºğœ…\kappa by solving f(t)â€‹(Ïƒ(t))=Îºsuperscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡superscriptğœğ‘¡ğœ…f^{(t)}(\sigma^{(t)})=\kappa after receiving ğ‘¾i(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¾ğ‘¡ğ‘–{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i}, which decides the added noise Ïƒ(t)superscriptğœğ‘¡\sigma^{(t)}.

5.2 Limiting Channel Capacity in Data Space

For a controlled parameter channel, our target is to constrain the transmitted information at round tğ‘¡t, i.e., Iâ€‹(ğ‘«;ğ‘¾~o(t)|ğ‘¾i(t))ğ¼ğ‘«conditionalsubscriptsuperscript~ğ‘¾ğ‘¡ğ‘œsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¾ğ‘¡ğ‘–I({\bm{D}};\widetilde{{\bm{W}}}^{(t)}_{o}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i}). Based on Thm.Â 2, there are two steps for solving the equation C(t)=Îºsuperscriptğ¶ğ‘¡ğœ…C^{(t)}=\kappa in the parameter space: the eigen-decomposition of ğšº(t)superscriptğšºğ‘¡{\bm{\Sigma}}^{(t)} and solving the high order equation with corresponding eigenvalues. Whereas, ğ‘¾o(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¾ğ‘¡ğ‘œ{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o} is a high-dimensional and time-variant parameter, which leads to an extremely large number of calculations. Hence, the implementation of the aforementioned method in the parameter space is computationally expensive.

Regarding ğ‘¾o(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¾ğ‘¡ğ‘œ{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o} in Fig.Â 2, when ğ‘¾i(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¾ğ‘¡ğ‘–{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i} is observed, it is conditional independent with the previous parameters ğ‘¾âˆ—(s)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¾ğ‘ {\bm{W}}^{(s)}_{*}, âˆ€s<tfor-allğ‘ ğ‘¡\forall s<t, and all of the previous local learning processes. Therefore, if ğ‘¾i(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¾ğ‘¡ğ‘–{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i} is observed, ğ‘¾o(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¾ğ‘¡ğ‘œ{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o} is purely decided by the local learning process at round tğ‘¡t, i.e., ğ‘«â†’ğ‘¾o(t)|ğ‘¾i(t)â†’ğ‘«conditionalsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¾ğ‘¡ğ‘œsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¾ğ‘¡ğ‘–{\bm{D}}\rightarrow{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i}. Then based on these properties, we design a random function Mâ€‹(â‹…)ğ‘€â‹…M(\cdot) to map the raw data ğ‘«ğ‘«{\bm{D}} to the noisy data ğ‘«~~ğ‘«\widetilde{{\bm{D}}}, and then utilize the noisy data for the local training, i.e., ğ‘¾~o(t)=ğ‘¾i(t)âˆ’Î·â‹…âˆ‡ğ‘¾Fâ€‹(ğ‘¾i(t);ğ‘«~)subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘¾ğ‘¡ğ‘œsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¾ğ‘¡ğ‘–â‹…ğœ‚subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¾ğ¹subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¾ğ‘¡ğ‘–~ğ‘«\widetilde{{\bm{W}}}^{(t)}_{o}={\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i}-\eta\cdot\nabla_{{\bm{W}}}F({\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i};\widetilde{{\bm{D}}}).

If we use the random function Mâ€‹(â‹…)ğ‘€â‹…M(\cdot) before the local learning process, the variables form a Markov Chain, i.e., ğ‘«â†’ğ‘«~â†’ğ‘¾o(t)|ğ‘¾i(t)â†’ğ‘«~ğ‘«â†’conditionalsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¾ğ‘¡ğ‘œsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¾ğ‘¡ğ‘–{\bm{D}}\rightarrow\widetilde{{\bm{D}}}\rightarrow{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i}. According to the DPI [15], we have

Iâ€‹(ğ‘«;ğ‘¾o(t)|ğ‘¾i(t))â‰¤Iâ€‹(ğ‘«;ğ‘«~|ğ‘¾i(t))=Iâ€‹(ğ‘«;ğ‘«~),ğ¼ğ‘«conditionalsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¾ğ‘¡ğ‘œsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¾ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ¼ğ‘«conditional~ğ‘«subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¾ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ¼ğ‘«~ğ‘«I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i})\leq I({\bm{D}};\widetilde{{\bm{D}}}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i})=I({\bm{D}};\widetilde{{\bm{D}}}), (16)

where the last equality results from the independence between Mâ€‹(â‹…)ğ‘€â‹…M(\cdot) and ğ‘¾i(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¾ğ‘¡ğ‘–{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i}. Therefore, we can bound Iâ€‹(ğ‘«;ğ‘«~)ğ¼ğ‘«~ğ‘«I({\bm{D}};\widetilde{{\bm{D}}}) so as to restrict Iâ€‹(ğ‘«;ğ‘¾o(t)|ğ‘¾i(t))ğ¼ğ‘«conditionalsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¾ğ‘¡ğ‘œsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¾ğ‘¡ğ‘–I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i}). Moreover, bounding Iâ€‹(ğ‘«;ğ‘«~)ğ¼ğ‘«~ğ‘«I({\bm{D}};\widetilde{{\bm{D}}}) enables us to limit the channel capacity in the data space. Specifically, we use ğ‘«~=Mâ€‹(ğ‘«)=ğ‘«+ğƒ~ğ‘«ğ‘€ğ‘«ğ‘«ğƒ\widetilde{{\bm{D}}}=M({\bm{D}})={\bm{D}}+{\bm{\xi}} as the random function, where ğƒâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(ğŸ,ğšºğƒ)similar-toğƒğ’©0subscriptğšºğƒ{\bm{\xi}}\sim{\mathcal{N}}(\bm{0},{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{\xi}}}), and the key parameter is ğšºğƒsubscriptğšºğƒ{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{\xi}}}.

The rationale of constraining transmitted information in data space. In addition to the upper bound derived by DPI, we can explain the rationale of constraining in data space by Taylorâ€™s expansion for a more comprehensible analysis. Specifically, if we use a Gaussian noise in the data space to constrain the information leakage, we can expand the gradient mapping as follows

âˆ‡ğ‘¾Fâ€‹(ğ‘¾;ğ‘«+ğƒ)subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¾ğ¹ğ‘¾ğ‘«ğƒ\displaystyle\nabla_{{\bm{W}}}F({\bm{W}};{\bm{D}}+\bm{\xi}) =\displaystyle= âˆ‡ğ‘¾Fâ€‹(ğ‘¾;ğ‘«)+âˆ‡ğ‘«âˆ‡ğ‘¾â¡Fâ€‹(ğ‘¾;ğ‘«)Tâ‹…ğƒsubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¾ğ¹ğ‘¾ğ‘«â‹…subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘«subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¾ğ¹superscriptğ‘¾ğ‘«Tğƒ\displaystyle\nabla_{{\bm{W}}}F({\bm{W}};{\bm{D}})+\nabla_{{\bm{D}}}\nabla_{{\bm{W}}}F({\bm{W}};{\bm{D}})^{\text{T}}\cdot\bm{\xi}
+Oâ€‹(â€–ğƒâ€–2).ğ‘‚superscriptnormğƒ2\displaystyle+O(\|\bm{\xi}\|^{2}). (17)

Eq.Â (5.2) indicates that constraining the transmitted information in the data space is equivalent to adding an adaptive noise âˆ‡ğ‘«âˆ‡ğ‘¾â¡Fâ€‹(ğ‘¾;ğ‘«)Tâ‹…ğƒâ‹…subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘«subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¾ğ¹superscriptğ‘¾ğ‘«Tğƒ\nabla_{{\bm{D}}}\nabla_{{\bm{W}}}F({\bm{W}};{\bm{D}})^{\text{T}}\cdot\bm{\xi} to the parameter.

Moreover, the coefficient âˆ‡ğ‘«âˆ‡ğ‘¾â¡Fâ€‹(ğ‘¾;ğ‘«)subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘«subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¾ğ¹ğ‘¾ğ‘«\nabla_{{\bm{D}}}\nabla_{{\bm{W}}}F({\bm{W}};{\bm{D}})is the variation of âˆ‡ğ‘¾Fâ€‹(ğ‘¾;ğ‘«)subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¾ğ¹ğ‘¾ğ‘«\nabla_{{\bm{W}}}F({\bm{W}};{\bm{D}}). If âˆ‡ğ‘¾Fâ€‹(ğ‘¾;ğ‘«)subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¾ğ¹ğ‘¾ğ‘«\nabla_{{\bm{W}}}F({\bm{W}};{\bm{D}}) changes significantly according to the data ğ‘«ğ‘«{\bm{D}}, which means the gradient has a high distinction degree with regard to the data, i.e., the gradient leaks more information, the large coefficient will provide strong privacy protection. Otherwise, the small coefficient leads to better utility without violating the privacy requirements.

Additionally, Fig.Â 5 provides a toy example for understanding the rationale of constraining in the data space. Specifically, we set Dâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(âˆ’1,1)similar-toğ·ğ’©11D\sim\mathcal{N}(-1,1) and our target is to decide the model Wğ‘ŠW that minimizes Fâ€‹(W;D)=W2â€‹Dğ¹ğ‘Šğ·superscriptğ‘Š2ğ·F(W;D)=W^{2}D through gradient descent. Particularly, we require the information leakage to be less than 111, i.e., C(t)=1superscriptğ¶ğ‘¡1C^{(t)}=1. As illustrated in Fig.Â 5, when we use the method in the parameter space to limit C(t)=1superscriptğ¶ğ‘¡1C^{(t)}=1 at W(t)=2superscriptğ‘Šğ‘¡2W^{(t)}=2, i.e., adding the noise Î¾âˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(0,16e2âˆ’1)similar-toğœ‰ğ’©016superscriptğ‘’21\xi\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\frac{16}{e^{2}-1}) to the gradient âˆ‡WFâ€‹(W;D)=2â€‹Wâ€‹Dsubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘Šğ¹ğ‘Šğ·2ğ‘Šğ·\nabla_{W}F(W;D)=2\,WD, the resulting noise cannot guarantee C(t+1)=1superscriptğ¶ğ‘¡11C^{(t+1)}=1 at next round W(t+1)=6superscriptğ‘Šğ‘¡16W^{(t+1)}=6 (we set the learning rate to 111), which implies that we need to recalculate the covariance matrix for the noise at each round. On the contrary, constraining in the data space (adding the noise Î¾âˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(0,1e2âˆ’1)similar-toğœ‰ğ’©01superscriptğ‘’21\xi\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\frac{1}{e^{2}-1}) to the data Dğ·D) results in an adaptive noise to guarantee C(t)=1superscriptğ¶ğ‘¡1C^{(t)}=1 for all tğ‘¡t regardless of W(t)superscriptğ‘Šğ‘¡W^{(t)}, leading to the Oâ€‹(1)ğ‘‚1O(1) time-complexity for achieving the privacy requirement.

Personalized Channel. In practice, the relative importance of different attributes in data is different. For example, [62] claims that for online diagnosis, our target is to extract disease-relevant features but remove identity features from the facial images of patients, which means we add more noise to the identity features compared to the disease-relevant features. For analyzing the problem, we assume the relative importance of different dimensions is ğœ·=(Î²0,â‹¯,Î²dâˆ’1)Tğœ·superscriptsubscriptğ›½0â‹¯subscriptğ›½ğ‘‘1ğ‘‡\bm{\beta}=(\beta_{0},\cdots,\beta_{d-1})^{T}, e.g., (height, weight)=(1, 2) represents the relative importance of the height to the weight is 1:2:121:2.

The relative importance decides the level of noise addition. In other words, if the attribute is more important, we add more noise to it for stronger protection. To utilize the prior knowledge ğœ·ğœ·\bm{\beta}, we chose ğšºğƒ=Ïƒâ‹…diagâ¡(ğœ·)subscriptğšºğƒâ‹…ğœdiagğœ·{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{\xi}}}=\sigma\cdot\operatorname{\mathrm{diag}}(\bm{\beta}). According to the proof of Thm.Â 2, Ïƒğœ\sigma is decided by

fâ€‹(Ïƒ)=lnâ€‹det[ğšºğ‘«+Ïƒâ‹…diagâ¡(ğœ·)]2â€‹âˆ‘i=1dlnâ¡(Ïƒâ‹…Î²i)=Îº.ğ‘“ğœdelimited-[]subscriptğšºğ‘«â‹…ğœdiagğœ·2superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘‘â‹…ğœsubscriptğ›½ğ‘–ğœ…f(\sigma)=\frac{\ln\det[{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{D}}}+\sigma\cdot\operatorname{\mathrm{diag}}(\bm{\beta})]}{2\sum_{i=1}^{d}\ln(\sigma\cdot\beta_{i})}=\kappa. (20)

However, the intrinsic correlations of local data bring difficulties in solving Eq.Â (20), so we derive the following theorem for simplifying the calculation.

Theorem 3 (Upper bound of Personalized Channel.).

where dğ‘‘d represent the dimension of ğšºğšº{\bm{\Sigma}}, then we have

Finally, we visualize ğ‘«~~ğ‘«\widetilde{{\bm{D}}} of different implementations according to different channel capacities in Fig.Â 5. Moreover, we discuss the advantages and the disadvantages of different channel implementations in AppendixÂ G.

Furthermore, constraining in the data space brings two advantages: first, compared to the parameter space, data space is white-box, low-dimensional, and time-invariant. Second, in the data space, the relative importance of attributes is preserved, which makes it easier to leverage prior knowledge.

Guidelines for noise injection. In summary, for defending against DRA, the important target is to restrict the transmitted information by noise addition. Here we provide guidelines for the noise injection:

  • â€¢

    For privacy-enhancing techniques (e.g., DP and gradient compression) in FL, the reconstruction error for DRA is theoretically above a threshold (Thm.Â 1) when we restrict the transmitted information within Îºğœ…\kappa. It can be achieved by solving fâ€‹(Ïƒ)=Îºğ‘“ğœğœ…f(\sigma)=\kappa, where fâ€‹(Ïƒ)ğ‘“ğœf(\sigma) is defined in Eq.Â (18). This equation decides the injection noise with corresponding statistics.

  • â€¢

    For defending against DRA in FL, we can inject noise to the training data instead of transmitted parameters. This transformation can produce an adaptive noise, which reduces the computational complexity brought by the high dimensional and time-variant system in FL.

  • â€¢

    For any pre-processing process such as embedding, we can get the same theoretical guarantee by substituting ğšºeâ€‹mâ€‹bâ€‹eâ€‹dâ€‹dâ€‹iâ€‹nâ€‹gsubscriptğšºğ‘’ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘”{\bm{\Sigma}}_{embedding} for ğšºğ‘«subscriptğšºğ‘«{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{D}}} in Eq.Â (18), where ğšºeâ€‹mâ€‹bâ€‹eâ€‹dâ€‹dâ€‹iâ€‹nâ€‹gsubscriptğšºğ‘’ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘”{\bm{\Sigma}}_{embedding} and ğšºğ‘«subscriptğšºğ‘«{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{D}}} are covariance matrixes calculated by embeddings and data, respectively.

  • â€¢

    In our method, a larger batch size leads to a tighter upper bound and a stronger ability to defend against DRA.

5.3 Channel Capacity for Existing Methods

With Thm.Â 1 and Thm.Â 2, we can analyze existing methods for defending against DRA by the channel capacity C(t)superscriptğ¶ğ‘¡C^{(t)}.

Existing privacy-enhancing methods in FL can be divided into three categories: perturbation, compression, and utilizing large batch size. The method of perturbation is represented by DP. Moreover, we demonstrate that for defending against DRA, the methods of gradient compression and utilizing large batch size are equivalent to adding more noise for perturbation, and the intrinsic mechanism of them are restricting the transmitted information.

Perturbation. As a method with theoretical guarantee, DP focuses on the problem of protecting individual information. In this work, we consider the event-level DP [40, 36] because we focus on the privacy issue for a specific client (i.e., the victim). That is, whether the attacker can reconstruct the local dataset with the victimâ€™s shared parameters. Specifically, the widely used DP technique in FL is the Gaussian mechanism, thus we analyze the Gaussian mechanism in this section. A typical process of the Gaussian mechanism for (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP consists of two stages: gradient clipping, which guarantees the sensitivity of the gradient is bounded; noise addition, which provides the (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP guarantee based on the bounded sensitivity. To analyze DP based on information theory, we have the following theorem.

Theorem 4 (Channel capacity for DP).

In FL, if the sensitivity of the gradient mapping is upper bounded by Sğ‘†S, i.e., â€–ğ â€–2â‰¤Ssubscriptnormğ 2ğ‘†\|{\bm{g}}\|_{2}\leq S, the channel capacity of (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP, i.e., CDâ€‹Psubscriptğ¶ğ·ğ‘ƒC_{DP}, is upper bounded by following formulas:

  1. â€ƒ(1)

    CDâ€‹Pâ‰¤Bâ‹…S2Ïƒ,subscriptğ¶ğ·ğ‘ƒâ‹…ğµsuperscriptğ‘†2ğœC_{DP}\leq\frac{B\cdot S^{2}}{\sigma},

  2. â€ƒ(2)

    CDâ€‹Pâ‰¤Bâ‹…Ïµ22â€‹logâ¡(1.25/Î´),subscriptğ¶ğ·ğ‘ƒâ‹…ğµsuperscriptitalic-Ïµ221.25ğ›¿C_{DP}\leq\frac{B\cdot\epsilon^{2}}{2\log(1.25/\delta)},

where BğµB represents the batch size and Ïƒğœ\sigma is the noise scale.

Compared to the conventional DP theorem, Thm.Â 4 indicates that batch size BğµB is a key factor of the defense ability to defend against DRA, which has been overlooked by prior literature. Specifically, increasing BğµB reduces DPâ€™s ability to defend against DRA, which has been validated by experiments in Fig.Â 8 (the details are explained in AppendixÂ D).

Compression. Another defense technique is compression, it intuitively focuses on reducing transmitted information by reducing the dimension of shared parameters. However, most of these methods lack theoretical guarantees.

Specifically, information is contained in each dimension of the gradient (i.e., the parameter), and the channel capacity decreases accordingly when we reduce the dimension of it. If we analyze the compression in the eigenspace, dimension reduction can be theoretically described by Thm.Â 2. Specifically, the total channel capacity is C(t)=12â€‹âˆ‘i=1dlnâ¡Î»i(t)+ÏƒÏƒsuperscriptğ¶ğ‘¡12superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘‘subscriptsuperscriptğœ†ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğœğœC^{(t)}=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{i=1}^{d}\ln\frac{\lambda^{(t)}_{i}+\sigma}{\sigma}, and the general term 12â€‹lnâ¡Î»i(t)+ÏƒÏƒ12subscriptsuperscriptğœ†ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğœğœ\frac{1}{2}\ln\frac{\lambda^{(t)}_{i}+\sigma}{\sigma} represents the channel capacity of the iğ‘–i-th dimension. Compressing the iğ‘–i-th dimension in the eigenspace, i.e., setting Î»i(t)=0subscriptsuperscriptğœ†ğ‘¡ğ‘–0\lambda^{(t)}_{i}=0, leads the channel capacity of iğ‘–i-th dimension to be 00, thereby reducing the total channel capacity. As illustrated in Fig.Â 8, when we compress the gradient, i.e., setting eigenvalues to be 00, the results are equivalent to adding more noise for perturbation. As displayed in Fig.Â 8, we also conduct experiments to validate our theoretical result, the experiments indicate that the improvement of the defense ability becomes more significant when we compress the dimension with a larger eigenvalue (the details are explained in AppendixÂ D). Due to the space limitation, we put the detailed analysis of compression in AppendixÂ E.

Large Batch Size. Another defense strategy for privacy protection in FL is utilizing large batch size [66]. Our model can theoretically formalize this strategy. If we denote the batch size as BğµB, then the gradient in mini-batch SGD is 1Bâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Bâˆ‡ğ‘¾Fâ€‹(ğ‘¾i(t);ğ‘«i)1ğµsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğµsubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¾ğ¹subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¾ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–\frac{1}{B}\sum_{i=1}^{B}\nabla_{{\bm{W}}}F({\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i};\;{\bm{D}}_{i}), where {ğ‘«i}i=1Bsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘«ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğµ\{{\bm{D}}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{B} represents the set of iid data points sampled from the dataset. The covariance matrix with large batch size is scaled by BğµB, i.e., ğšºB(t)=1Bâ€‹ğšº(t)subscriptsuperscriptğšºğ‘¡ğµ1ğµsuperscriptğšºğ‘¡{\bm{\Sigma}}^{(t)}_{B}=\frac{1}{B}{\bm{\Sigma}}^{(t)}. Hence, with substituting ğšºB(t)subscriptsuperscriptğšºğ‘¡ğµ{\bm{\Sigma}}^{(t)}_{B} for ğšº(t)superscriptğšºğ‘¡{\bm{\Sigma}}^{(t)} in Thm.Â 2, we have

CB(t)=fB(t)â€‹(Ïƒ):=12â€‹âˆ‘i=1dlnâ¡(Î»i(t)/B+Ïƒ)Ïƒ.subscriptsuperscriptğ¶ğ‘¡ğµsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğµğ‘¡ğœassign12superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘‘subscriptsuperscriptğœ†ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğµğœğœC^{(t)}_{B}=f_{B}^{(t)}(\sigma):=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{i=1}^{d}\ln\frac{(\lambda^{(t)}_{i}/B+\sigma)}{\sigma}. (24)

With the constant noise addition, C(t)superscriptğ¶ğ‘¡C^{(t)} is a decreasing function of BğµB, which means we can enhance the ability to defend against DRA by increasing BğµB. Fig.Â 8 experimentally validates this theory and we put the details of Fig.Â 8 in AppendixÂ D due to the space limitation.

Guidelines for hyper-parameters. Finally, to improve existing defensive algorithms, we provide several guidelines for choosing the hyper-parameters in FL:

  • â€¢

    A smaller batch size in DP algorithm is more effective to defend against DRA.

  • â€¢

    Compressing the dimension with larger eigenvalue results in the stronger ability to defend against DRA.

  • â€¢

    A larger batch size leads to a stronger defense ability to defend against DRA when we add a constant noise to the parameter during training.

6 Experiment

In this section, we conduct experiments with various models and datasets to validate our theories and compare our methods with other privacy-enhancing techniques. All experiments are performed upon a Supermicro SYS-420GP-TNR server with two Intel(R) Xeon(R) Gold 6348 CPUs (2Ã—\times28 cores), Ubuntu 18.04.1, 10GB memory, and four NVIDIA A100 PCIe 80GB GPUs. Meanwhile, to eliminate the impact of randomness, each experiment is repeated 10 times.

6.1 Experimental Settings

Datasets. Dataset is a task-dependent factor, which means we cannot change the dataset when the training task is decided. In our experiments, we resize the data to 32*32 for comparison, and utilize four classical datasets, including CIFAR10 [31], CelebA [41], SVHN [47], and Fashion-MNIST [60].

Basic Models. In this work, we experiment with four classical model architectures, including LeNet [34], AlexNet [32], VGG16 [52], and ResNet10 [27]. Moreover, model architectures are task-independent, we can select architectures according to different goals, e.g., utility or privacy.

Attacks. We test our methods on two typical attacks in FL: MIA and DRA, the details of different attacks are as follows.

Membership Inference Attack. For MIA, we use the white-box attackÂ [46, 39]. Meanwhile, we employ a partial knowledge attacker, which means the attacker can access to part of the training dataset. In this case, the attacker has much stronger background knowledge. Moreover, we use four inputs for attackingÂ [39]: the samplesâ€™ ranked posteriors, classification loss, gradients of the last layer, and one-hot encoding of the true label. These inputs are fed into different neural networks to get different embeddings, then we concatenate all embeddings as the input of a 4-layer MLP to get the inference.

Data Reconstruction Attack. For DRA, we employ two representative attacks: model inversion attack and gradient inversion attack. For model inversion attackÂ [20, 39], we first construct a dummy input with auxiliary information (i.e., the mean value of images that are not in the training dataset) as the input for the target model, then utilize different target labels to optimize the dummy input. We use Adam optimizer with a learning rate of 1e-2 for 600 iterations. Additionally, we employ the settings proposed by Geiping et al.Â [21] to investigate the defense ability for gradient inversion attacks.

Metric. We evaluate our design with various criteria, including the model utility, the defense capability against different attacks, the utility-privacy trade-offs, and the efficiency. To this end, we employ the following metrics for evaluation.

Test Accuracy. FL searches for an accurate model for classification, hence we use test accuracy as the metric for utility.

AUC. We use the attack AUC to measure the attack performance for MIA. Itâ€™s worth noting that a smaller AUC means a stronger defense capability.

MSE. We use MSE as the main metric for DRA since MSE is a general metric that indicates the convergence of random variables. That is, if the MSE of two random variables is 0, we conclude that they have identical distributions [58], which means a perfect reconstruction. Additionally, a large MSE means a stronger ability to defend against DRA. Moreover, we also utilize PSNR, SSIM, and Cosine Similarity to evaluate the defense ability, we put these results in AppendixÂ F due to the space limitation. Specifically, for model inversion attacks, we calculate the metric between the reversed data and the center of the corresponding class for different classes. We use the median of all classes as the final metric. For gradient inversion attacks, we employ the mean value of the metric between the reconstructed data and the target data.

General Defense Capability (GDC). For evaluating the comprehensive defense capability, we use the improvements of the aforementioned attacks. Specifically, for MIA, we define the improvement as

Iâ€‹Mâ€‹PMâ€‹Iâ€‹A=(Aâ€‹Uâ€‹Cwâ€‹iâ€‹tâ€‹hâ€‹oâ€‹uâ€‹tâ€‹_â€‹dâ€‹eâ€‹fâˆ’Aâ€‹Uâ€‹C)/Aâ€‹Uâ€‹Cwâ€‹iâ€‹tâ€‹hâ€‹oâ€‹uâ€‹tâ€‹_â€‹dâ€‹eâ€‹f.ğ¼ğ‘€subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ¼ğ´ğ´ğ‘ˆsubscriptğ¶ğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘¡â„ğ‘œğ‘¢ğ‘¡_ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘“ğ´ğ‘ˆğ¶ğ´ğ‘ˆsubscriptğ¶ğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘¡â„ğ‘œğ‘¢ğ‘¡_ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘“IMP_{MIA}=({AUC}_{without\_def}-{AUC})/{AUC}_{without\_def}.

While the improvement for DRA is

Iâ€‹Mâ€‹PDâ€‹Râ€‹A=(1Mâ€‹Sâ€‹Ewâ€‹iâ€‹tâ€‹hâ€‹oâ€‹uâ€‹tâ€‹_â€‹dâ€‹eâ€‹fâˆ’1Mâ€‹Sâ€‹E)/1Mâ€‹Sâ€‹Ewâ€‹iâ€‹tâ€‹hâ€‹oâ€‹uâ€‹tâ€‹_â€‹dâ€‹eâ€‹f.ğ¼ğ‘€subscriptğ‘ƒğ·ğ‘…ğ´1ğ‘€ğ‘†subscriptğ¸ğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘¡â„ğ‘œğ‘¢ğ‘¡_ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘“1ğ‘€ğ‘†ğ¸1ğ‘€ğ‘†subscriptğ¸ğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘¡â„ğ‘œğ‘¢ğ‘¡_ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘“IMP_{DRA}=(\frac{1}{MSE_{without\_def}}-\frac{1}{MSE})/\frac{1}{{MSE}_{without\_def}}.

Finally, we define general defense capability as

Gâ€‹Dâ€‹C=(Iâ€‹Mâ€‹PMâ€‹Iâ€‹A+Iâ€‹Mâ€‹PDâ€‹Râ€‹A)/2,ğºğ·ğ¶ğ¼ğ‘€subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ¼ğ´ğ¼ğ‘€subscriptğ‘ƒğ·ğ‘…ğ´2GDC=(IMP_{MIA}+IMP_{DRA})/{2},

and a larger Gâ€‹Dâ€‹Cğºğ·ğ¶GDC means a stronger defense capability.

Default parameter configuration. In our experiments, we mainly utilize natural channel to investigate the channel parameters. Specifically, we fix the optimization rounds as n=1Ã—104ğ‘›1superscript104n=1\times 10^{4} and utilize Îºğœ…\kappa in {50, 100, 200, 300} to investigate the effect of different channel capacities. Additionally, we fix Îº=300ğœ…300\kappa=300 and utilize Tâ€‹oâ€‹tâ€‹aâ€‹lâ€‹Iâ€‹nâ€‹fâ€‹oğ‘‡ğ‘œğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘™ğ¼ğ‘›ğ‘“ğ‘œTotalInfo in {5Ã—105,1Ã—106,2Ã—106,3Ã—106}5superscript1051superscript1062superscript1063superscript106\{5\times 10^{5},1\times 10^{6},2\times 10^{6},3\times 10^{6}\} to investigate the effect of different nğ‘›n, where n=âŒŠTâ€‹oâ€‹tâ€‹aâ€‹lâ€‹Iâ€‹nâ€‹fâ€‹oÎºâŒ‹ğ‘›ğ‘‡ğ‘œğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘™ğ¼ğ‘›ğ‘“ğ‘œğœ…n=\lfloor\frac{TotalInfo}{\kappa}\rfloor and âŒŠâ‹…âŒ‹â‹…\lfloor\cdot\rfloor is the floor function. We will explicitly explain it when we utilize different configurations.

6.2 The Effect of Controlled Channel

Impact of channel capacity (Îºğœ…\kappa). Îºğœ…\kappa represents the upper bound of information leakage in a single training round. As illustrated in Fig.Â 10, when we enhance the channel, i.e., increase Îºğœ…\kappa, the accuracy increases accordingly regardless of the datasets and the model architectures, which means a wider channel leads to a better utility. However, the increasing utility is at the cost of reducing data privacy. Fig.Â 10 displays the corresponding defense capability against DRA. Specifically, for DRA attacks, the MSE decreases according to the increasing Îºğœ…\kappa, which means the reconstructed data is closer to the target data. These results indicate that in the practical scenario, we can adjust channel capacity by Îºğœ…\kappa to balance the utility and the privacy according to various requirements.

Moreover, we explicitly display the utility-privacy tradeoff in Fig.Â 11. Specifically, the utility increases with the increase of channel capacity Îºğœ…\kappa, while the ability of privacy protection decreases with the increase of Îºğœ…\kappa. These results are reasonable since channel capacity constrains the transmitted information, and the reconstruction error, i.e., the MSE, can be theoretically restricted when the transmitted information is limited based on Thm.Â 1. Meanwhile, more available information results in a more accurate model, indicating that the adjustable channel capacity can be utilized to balance the utility-privacy tradeoff.

Impact of optimization rounds (nğ‘›n). Different from the channel capacity Cğ¶C, the number of optimization rounds nğ‘›n affects the parameter channel through another dimension: information accumulation. Similarly, the results in Fig.Â 14 and 14 imply that nğ‘›n is another parameter to influence the utility and the defense ability of the controlled channel. Increasing nğ‘›n results in obtaining more information from the local dataset, thereby enhancing the utility while reducing the defense ability.

Defense ability against gradient inversion attack. We randomly select 30 images from each dataset as the target data and evaluate the defense abilities to defend against gradient inversion attacks. As shown in Fig.Â 14, the MSE of data reconstruction consistently increases as we decrease the threshold Îºğœ…\kappa, which means a smaller Îºğœ…\kappa leads to a stronger ability to defend against DRA. The MSE of the White Channel and the Personalized Channel are larger than the Natural Channel, indicating that the other two methods provide stronger defense capability compared to the Natural Channel.

6.3 Comparing with Other Methods

In this section, we compare our methods with two classic perturbation mechanisms: DP-SGD [1] and DP-PSAC [59]. Specifically, DP-SGD first utilizes DP for ML and DP-PSAC is the state-of-art method to improve DP-SGD by adaptively clipping the gradients.

Utility-Privacy trade-off. We first compare our methods with DP-SGD and DP-PSAC in the utility-privacy plane. The plane is formed by two axes: the xğ‘¥x-axis represents GDC, which is the general ability for privacy protection. While the yğ‘¦y-axis represents the accuracy, which represents the utility. For all methods, we use the model of LeNet and fix the rounds as n=1Ã—104ğ‘›1superscript104n=1\times 10^{4}. The results are displayed in Fig.Â 16. Specifically, in our methods, we use channel capacity in {50, 100, 200, 300} for the Natural Channel, and {500, 800, 1000, 1500} for the White Channel and the Personalized Channel. Additionally, we use 1:50 in ğœ·ğœ·\bm{\beta} for the Personalized Channel to protect the attributes around the eyes (AppendixÂ B indicates the details of ğœ·ğœ·\bm{\beta}). For DP-SGD and DP-PSAC, we use the clipping bound S=1.0ğ‘†1.0S=1.0, Î´=1Ã—10âˆ’5ğ›¿1superscript105\delta=1\times 10^{-5} (Î´=3Ã—10âˆ’6ğ›¿3superscript106\delta=3\times 10^{-6} for CelebA), and the multiplier Ïƒğœ\sqrt{\sigma} in {0.8, 0.57, 0.46, 0.2066} (the corresponding privacy budget Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon for these DP training are {1.705, 5.120, 12.026, 331.668}, respectively) . According to Thm.Â 4, these Ïƒğœ\sigma result in channel capacities in {100, 200, 300, 1500} when we utilize B=64ğµ64B=64, which are identical to the channel capacities of our methods. As in Fig.Â 16, the Natural Channel achieves the best utility-privacy trade-off. The reason is that it utilizes the original importance to maintain the information in data attributes, and the constrained channel capacity ensures the ability to defend against DRA.

Comparison of the details in defense ability. To investigate the detailed defense ability of different methods, we decouple the defense capabilities to display them in the defense-defense plane. Specifically, xğ‘¥x-axis represents Iâ€‹Mâ€‹PDâ€‹Râ€‹Ağ¼ğ‘€subscriptğ‘ƒğ·ğ‘…ğ´IMP_{DRA} and yğ‘¦y-axis represents Iâ€‹Mâ€‹PMâ€‹Iâ€‹Ağ¼ğ‘€subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ¼ğ´IMP_{MIA}. As displayed in Fig.Â 16, DP specializes in defending against MIA but is weaker in defending against DRA, this is reasonable since DP focuses on protecting individual information. Compared to DP, our methods specialize in defending against DRA. Moreover, our methods achieve the best comprehensive defense capability for both attacks.

Efficiency of constraining in the data space. As displayed in Tab.Â 2, we compare the efficiency of our method with DP-SGD, which is a method that works in the parameter space. We use OPACUS 1.1.2 [63] for the implementation of DP-SGD. The results indicate that when we transform the operations to the data space, it significantly reduces the amount of calculation, i.e., the training time, especially when the dimension of the parameter increases.

7 Related Work

Differential Privacy. Differential Privacy [18] is an important technique for privacy protection. For the definition of differential privacy, MironovÂ [45] proposes to utilize RÃ©nyi divergence, which leads to compact and accurate privacy loss. Moreover, Abadi et al.Â [1] propose an empirical algorithm DP-SGD for applying DP to ML training, then multiple literature tries to improve the performance of DP-SGDÂ [3, 6, 9, 59]. Most of them focus on the utility, trying to adaptively clip the gradients or add suitable perturbations. For the application of DP, Levy et al.Â [36] propose to protect user-level DP instead of ensuring the privacy of individual samples, which makes DP more reliable to FL. Truex et al.Â [55] present a protocol LDP-Fed to formally ensure data privacy in collecting local parameters with high precision. However, DP is still vulnerable to DRA, several researchers indicate that they can reconstruct the data without violating the requirements of DPÂ [14, 17], implying that the algorithms are still vulnerable to DRA. Compared to DP, our work aims to defend against DRA based on information theory.

Limiting Mutual Information. Another related concept of privacy protection depends on MI. Several studies connect MI with DP by deriving the upper bound of MI for a distinct DP mechanismÂ [8, 4, 16]. For privacy protection, Li et al.Â [37] propose to train a feature extractor that minimizes MI between the output features and the assigned label while maximizing the MI between output features and the original data. Similarly, Osia et al.Â [48] propose to train an extractor with the variational lower bound for MI estimation. Moreover, Hannun et al.Â [25] utilize Fisher Information to measure the information leakage, and the conclusions are consistent with our theories. Finally, we can also model FL based on information theory [2, 57], which measures the MI between different variables in FL. Compared to the former methods, our technique models the communication channel of FL directly based on information theory and utilizes its upper bound to derive practical methods for constraining the transmitted information, which leads to the strong ability to defend against DRA.

8 Discussion and Conclusion

Our method constrains the information leakage of the black-box model according to an upper bound derived by maximum entropy distribution (LemmaÂ 1). We can tighten the upper bound by utilizing a large batch size or incorporating domain knowledge. Among them, utilizing large batch size for training causes the output distribution to be closer to a Gaussian distribution, while incorporating domain knowledge enables us to get more properties of the output distribution. If we get a tighter upper bound, the tradeoff between utility and privacy can be further improved.

In summary, as the reconstruction error of DRA is decided by the transmitted information, we build a channel model to measure the information leakage of the black-box model in FL. The model indicates that the amount of transmitted information is decided by the channel capacity Cğ¶C and the number of optimization rounds nğ‘›n. Guided by the model, we develop methods to constrain the channel capacity within a threshold Îºğœ…\kappa. Combining it with the limited optimization rounds nğ‘›n, the upper bound of the total transmitted information remains below nâ‹…Îºâ‹…ğ‘›ğœ…n\cdot\kappa, which ensures the ability to defend against DRA. Furthermore, we transform the operations of constraining channel capacity from the parameter space to the data space. The transformation significantly improves the training efficiency and the model accuracy under constrained information leakage. Finally, extensive experiments with real-world datasets validate the benefit of our methods.

Appendix A The detail explanation of DRA

For DRA in FL, the attacker aims to build a reconstruction ğ‘«^â€‹(ğ‘¾i,ğ‘¾o)^ğ‘«subscriptğ‘¾ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¾ğ‘œ\hat{{\bm{D}}}({\bm{W}}_{i},{\bm{W}}_{o}) to approximate the data ğ‘«ğ‘«{\bm{D}}, where ğ‘¾isubscriptğ‘¾ğ‘–{\bm{W}}_{i} and ğ‘¾osubscriptğ‘¾ğ‘œ{\bm{W}}_{o} are the transmitted parameters in FL. Moreover, if the MSE between ğ‘«^â€‹(ğ‘¾i,ğ‘¾o)^ğ‘«subscriptğ‘¾ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¾ğ‘œ\hat{{\bm{D}}}({\bm{W}}_{i},{\bm{W}}_{o}) and ğ‘«ğ‘«{\bm{D}} achieves 00, i.e., ğ”¼â€‹â€–ğ‘«^â€‹(ğ‘¾i,ğ‘¾o)âˆ’ğ‘«â€–2=0ğ”¼superscriptnorm^ğ‘«subscriptğ‘¾ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¾ğ‘œğ‘«20\mathbb{E}\|\hat{{\bm{D}}}({\bm{W}}_{i},{\bm{W}}_{o})-{\bm{D}}\|^{2}=0, we conclude that ğ‘«^â€‹(ğ‘¾i,ğ‘¾o)^ğ‘«subscriptğ‘¾ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¾ğ‘œ\hat{{\bm{D}}}({\bm{W}}_{i},{\bm{W}}_{o}) and ğ‘«ğ‘«{\bm{D}} have identical distributions [58].

Additionally, with the definition of ğ‘«ğ‘«{\bm{D}}, i.e., the random variable that follows the distribution of the local dataset, the MIA [10] can be viewed as inferring whether a particular data point belongs to the support set of ğ‘«ğ‘«{\bm{D}}.

Appendix B Details of the Prior Knowledge

For the Personalized Channel, the prior knowledge ğœ·ğœ·\bm{\beta} used in Sec.Â 6 is a 32âˆ—32âˆ—c3232ğ‘32*32*c tensor, where cğ‘c represents the number of image channel (e.g., c=1ğ‘1c=1 for Fashion-MNIST dataset and c=3ğ‘3c=3 for CIFAR-10 dataset, respectively). The number in ğœ·ğœ·\bm{\beta} represents the coefficient for the added noise, which means we add more noise to the dimension if the coefficient of this dimension is larger. In these experiments, we employ position-based prior knowledge, which means the prior knowledge for all image channels are identical. Therefore, the important parameters are the numbers of one channel, which is a 32âˆ—32323232*32 matrix (as displayed in Fig.Â 17).

Specifically, as we aim to protect the private information around eyes for the data in CelebA (as displayed in Fig.Â 5), we set the number of these positions (i.e., the sub-matrix with row 12 to 19 and column 8 to 23.) to be 505050, and set the rest number of the matrix to be 111. Therefore, this prior knowledge adds 505050 times noise to the chosen positions (i.e., the positions around the eyes) to provide stronger privacy protection for this area. Additionally, we also use this prior knowledge for other datasets, including Fashion-MNIST, CIFAR10, and SVHN.

C.3 Proof of TheoremÂ 2

Proof.

According to the relationship between mutual information and differential entropy, we have

C.5 Proof of TheoremÂ 4

Proof.

Appendix D Validating the theories of existing methods

The impact of batch size for DP and utilizing large batch size in defending against DRA. To improve the existing defense algorithm for defending against DRA, we design experiments to validate the roles of BğµB by gradient inversion attack on CIFAR-10. Specifically, to keep identical reconstruction difficulties for different BğµB, we only reconstruct one image from the gradient as the mean restoration ğ”¼â€‹[ğ‘«^]ğ”¼delimited-[]^ğ‘«\mathbb{E}[\hat{{\bm{D}}}]. Then we calculate the MSE between ğ”¼â€‹[ğ‘«^]ğ”¼delimited-[]^ğ‘«\mathbb{E}[\hat{{\bm{D}}}] and the mean value of local dataset ğ”¼â€‹[ğ‘«]ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘«\mathbb{E}[{\bm{D}}], i.e., â€–ğ”¼â€‹[ğ‘«^]âˆ’ğ”¼â€‹[ğ‘«]â€–2superscriptnormğ”¼delimited-[]^ğ‘«ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘«2\|\mathbb{E}[\hat{{\bm{D}}}]-\mathbb{E}[{\bm{D}}]\|^{2}. Due to the convexity of MSE, the difference between ğ‘«^^ğ‘«\hat{{\bm{D}}} and ğ‘«ğ‘«{\bm{D}} is lower bounded, i.e., ğ”¼â€‹â€–ğ‘«^âˆ’ğ‘«â€–2â‰¥â€–ğ”¼â€‹[ğ‘«^]âˆ’ğ”¼â€‹[ğ‘«]â€–2ğ”¼superscriptnorm^ğ‘«ğ‘«2superscriptnormğ”¼delimited-[]^ğ‘«ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘«2\mathbb{E}\|\hat{{\bm{D}}}-{\bm{D}}\|^{2}\geq\|\mathbb{E}[\hat{{\bm{D}}}]-\mathbb{E}[{\bm{D}}]\|^{2}. Moreover, we utilize clipping bound S=1.0ğ‘†1.0S=1.0 and the noise multiplier Ïƒ=1.3ğœ1.3\sigma=1.3 for the DP training. The results are displayed in Fig.Â 8. If we utilize DP for privacy protection, the performance for defending against DRA consistently decreases with an increasing BğµB. This phenomenon is consistent with Thm.Â 4, indicating that the small BğµB is beneficial for DP in defending against DRA.

Additionally, when we do not apply any defense technique for privacy, the defense ability increases according to the increasing BğµB. This phenomenon is consistent with Eq.Â (24) due to the intrinsic noise in the collected data. Moreover, the performance improvement becomes more significant when we add a constant noise to the parameters. The conclusion is that when we add a constant noise to the parameter, a larger BğµB leads to a stronger ability to defend against DRA.

The impact of eigenvalues in compression. We also validate our theories for compression on CIFAR-10 datasets. In these experiments, we utilize the gradient inversion attack to reconstruct data from the gradients. For the compression, we set the eigenvector to be ğŸ0\mathbf{0} to reduce the information in the corresponding dimension. Then we map the training data to the compressed eigenspace. For comparison, we only compress one dimension according to the eigenvalue. The results are displayed in Fig.Â 8. Specifically, the eigenvalues {Î»mâ€‹aâ€‹x,Î»1,Î»10}subscriptğœ†ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥subscriptğœ†1subscriptğœ†10\{\lambda_{max},\lambda_{1},\lambda_{10}\} are as follows: {222.21, 85.08, 9.91} for CIFAR10, {346.21, 71.01, 12.82} for CelebA, {313.0, 28.04, 4.67} for SVHN, and {101.88, 61.80, 3.21} for Fashion-MNIST. The experiment results demonstrate that the compression on the dimension with a larger eigenvalue leads to a stronger defensive ability to defend against DRA, which is consistent with our theories.

Compression. As for gradient compression, it is easy to understand that the compression mechanism reduces the information contained in parameters, and we can also formalize this intuition with our channel model.

Appendix F Additional Experiments

In this section, we display additional experimental results to evaluate our techniques. The results are summarized as follows:

  • â€¢

    The results for White Channel and Personalized Channel. Fig.Â 20 and Fig.Â 20 display the model accuracy and the defense ability to defend against DRA for White Channel. Meanwhile, Fig.Â 23 and Fig.Â 23 display the corresponding results for Personalized Channel. Specifically, these results are similar to the Natural Channel, when we increase the channel capacity, the model accuracy increases, while the defense ability decreases.

  • â€¢

    The defense ability for defending against MIA. The results in Fig.Â 20, Fig.Â 23, and Fig.Â 26 indicate that reducing channel capacity can also defend against MIA. Specifically, a smaller AUC means a stronger ability for defending against MIA, which indicates that it is difficult for an attacker to infer the membership property of the given data. When we constrain the transmitted information, the AUC for conducting MIA significantly decreases. Moreover, Fig.Â 26 exhibits a similar phenomenon when we restrict the optimization rounds nğ‘›n. All of these results demonstrate that constraining transmitted information can also defend against MIA.

  • â€¢

    Utility privacy tradeoff according to optimization rounds nğ‘›n. Fig.Â 24 displays the utility privacy tradeoff according to nğ‘›n. Similarly, we fix the channel capacity Îº=300ğœ…300\kappa=300, and vary the total transmitted information in {5Ã—1055superscript1055\times 10^{5}, 1Ã—1061superscript1061\times 10^{6}, 2Ã—1062superscript1062\times 10^{6}, 3Ã—1063superscript1063\times 10^{6}} (where n=âŒŠTâ€‹oâ€‹tâ€‹aâ€‹lâ€‹Iâ€‹nâ€‹fâ€‹oÎºâŒ‹ğ‘›ğ‘‡ğ‘œğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘™ğ¼ğ‘›ğ‘“ğ‘œğœ…n=\lfloor\frac{TotalInfo}{\kappa}\rfloor, where âŒŠâ‹…âŒ‹â‹…\lfloor\cdot\rfloor is the floor function.). Specifically, increasing nğ‘›n leads to more transmitted information, thus results in the increase in utility and the decrease in the ability of privacy protection. These results demonstrate that adjusting nğ‘›n can also influence the tradeoff between the utility and the privacy.

  • â€¢

    More metrics for evaluating the ability to defend against DRA. For random variables, MSE is 00 implies the convergence in mean, which further implies convergence in distribution, i.e., the distributions of these variables are identicalÂ [58]. Meanwhile, a smaller MSE indicates the reconstructed data distribution gets closer to the target distribution. Fig.Â 30 displays the MSE for CelebA, SVHN, and Fashion-MNIST. The results indicate that when we constrain the transmitted information, the MSE increases, which indicates that it is more difficult for an attacker to conduct DRA attacks.
    In addition to the MSE, we also utilize other metrics such as PSNR, SSIM, and Cosine Similarity to measure the similarity between the reconstructed data and the target data. Among them, PSNR is the most popular metric to measure the quality of the processed image, SSIM is the second most popular metric for this target [33], and Cosine Similarity is the most familiar metric for us to measure the similarity of two vectors. For all of them, the larger value means more similarities in the reconstruction, which indicates the weaker ability to defend against DRA. Fig.Â 29 and Fig.Â 31 display the results of PSNR, Fig.Â 29 and Fig.Â 32 show the reconstruction error by SSIM, Fig.Â 29 and Fig.Â 33 utilize Cosine Similarity to measure the quality of reconstructed data. All of these results demonstrate that reducing channel capacity can effectively reduce the quality of reconstruction. In other words, our method can enhance the ability to defend against DRA, which is consistent with Thm.Â 1.
    Particularly, we put emphasis on the metric of MSE. We choose MSE as the main metric for three reasons: first, MSE indicates the convergence of random variablesÂ [58]. That is, if the MSE of two random variables is 00, we conclude that they have identical distributions, which means a perfect reconstruction. Second, Thm.Â 1 indicates that restricting transmitted information can provide the theoretical lower bound for MSE. Finally, MSE is a general metric for random variables.

Appendix G Discussion of the Channels

In this section, we summarize the advantages and disadvantages of the Natural Channel, the While Channel, and the Personalized Channel as follows:

  • â€¢

    Natural Channel. It preserves the relative importance of different attributes, hence it maintains the information contained in the dataset, which is beneficial for the model utility in FL. However, Natural Channel cannot incorporate prior knowledge into the protecting process, hence we cannot adjust the algorithm according to the requirement when channel capacity is decided.

  • â€¢

    White Channel. It provides a much stronger defense ability to defend against DRA when there is no prior knowledge. It treats the importance of each attribute to be equal, which adds more noise to the dimension with more information to achieve such stronger protection. However, the computation complexity of the White Channel is higher than the Natural Channel because of the additional matrix multiplication.

  • â€¢

    Personalized Channel. It allows us to leverage prior knowledge of the attribute importance to the protection process, hence we can perform the better utility-privacy tradeoff. Whereas, in order to reduce the computation complexity, the Personalized Channel depends on an upper bound, which weakens this benefit accordingly.
